column1: Welcome to our show! Today, I am going to show you how to make the perfect mouthwatering sandwich! Are you ready? Let ’ s get started!
column2: Let ’ s start with the basics, bread. Bread is an important ingredient here. You need to remember one thing - choose the bread according to the following criteria, freshness, crumb and color. If you want a closed sandwich I recommend you first toast your bread in a toaster or oven, or grill it slightly until it gets a light brown color.
column3: Now that our bread is ready, let ’ s talk about the ingredients! Of course, each person ’ s palate is different, but I ’ m going to give you a few tips that you ’ ll be able to use when turning any sandwich into the perfect sandwich. I would strongly recommend you put fresh vegetables in your sandwich.
column4: Do not undervalue them as they play a big role in forming the taste and will make the sandwich more refreshing and light. The best choices here are evident — cucumbers, tomatoes, onions, sweet pepper or chilli, lettuce and, of course, herbs — you can ’ t go wrong with them. As for aubergines, mushrooms and asparagus, I would recommend you first grill them slightly with a little touch of olive oil.
column5: Last but not least, we have a wide variety of condiments that we can add to our perfect sandwich. We can be subtle and just add a touch of salt and pepper, or we can combine mustard sauce, mayonnaise, ketchup or even caviar to achieve a stronger flavor! It ’ s always a good idea to cut your sandwich in triangles or manageable pieces to avoid all your ingredients falling out and staining your shirt!
column6: That ’ s all the time we have for today, but join us next time where we ’ ll be going over how to make the perfect lasagna! Till next time!

column1: In 1986, a New Zealander Hackett popularized Bungee as a commercialized sport of mass entertainment. This sport is very challenging. It is a test of people's psychological ability of endurance. Especially when descending, as if they are watching a fast forward tape and when they bounce back, they sway around. The timid people will shrink back at the sight of it. Even if they jump off, they find it hard to avoid screaming with closed eyes. No wonder people give the title' brave' to anyone who jumps off.
column2: You see, the bungee participants take a deep breath when they stand at the starting spot and then, like diving, their heads are over heels and they jump off into the realm of the combination of heaven and earth. The wind roars at their ears and their bodies rapidly descend. They do not even have enough time to do several gymnastic movements and they are rebounded to the upper air by the cord.
column3: Entrusting life to the care of a rope indeed requires infinite courage.
column4: A young French fellow recalled his first bungee experience and said, " When I fastened the cord and walked to the platform, I was extremely nervous. When I looked down, I was nervous even more. If the cord had broken, I would be knocked to' bakemeat'. However, I knew my worries were unwanted. I was afraid if I retreated others might say something about me. I had to harden my heart and impose my head downward. I only felt wind wiring at my ears. My body rapidly descended. I thought that after only seven or eight seconds I was rebounded to upper air by the cord. In fact it was 30 seconds. Maybe because of my nervousness, I only felt seven or eight seconds. When rebounding to the high altitude, I felt a sudden sense of relief. I did not feel nervous very much, but very comfortable. "

column1: In China at least, coffee is often associated with an exotic, well-to-do bourgeois lifestyle. Coffee is often considered a hobby of the well-educated, middle-class people.
column2: Maybe that's why some young chaps often spend a whole afternoon in a coffee bar, surfing the net or just typewriting something with laptop. While they are savoring a coffee at a leisured pace, they are actually showing off!
column3: Yes. Behind a lifestyle, there is a culture. Young people easily become blind worshippers of a Westernized life. While they may not really like coffee, they think it desirable and enviable to be lavish with money in those high-consumption places.
column4: Then what about tea? We need to bear in mind in the first place that tea, rather than coffee, has been the most popular drink for the Chinese people.
column5: Well. Tea represents another facet of popular culture. While a coffee bar is usually quiet and resonates with soft, elegant music, a teahouse is often a noisy, crowded, public space. People visit teahouses to associate with others, playing chess, chatting, or simply listening to operas.
column6: What a pity that the traditional teahouses, as depicted by Lao She, keep fading away so quickly in this metropolis. It is not easy to find an old-fashioned teahouse that suits the ordinary people's spending power either. Teahouses of today all feature a cozy, comfortable environment, and high-quality services, but can easily cost you a good deal — just like a coffee bar.
column7: Well, that's true. In a sense, it is not so much what you drink that really counts, as where and how you drink.

column1: Television is undoubtedly a great invention, but one of the main criticisms of it is that people just aren't selective enough. Lesley, got a television. how do you pick out the sorts ofprogrammes you want to watch?

column3: Do you think of television though as a great time-waster?
column4: Un... I think it can be a time-waster and it depends on how particular people are about what they want to see... Mm, it can just be a sort total amusement for someone and totally consuming without reallyconsidering what it is they're watching.
column5: Aha, but how do you prevent it coming into your life and taking oversour evenings and at the same time perhaps get... get out of thetelevision some of the sort of best things... best programmes that... that undoubtedly are on television?
column6: Well, I suppose one of the problems is... will depend on what a person's life style is, and that if he has other outside interests which are equally important to him as television, he will then, you know, hmm. be more careful about which programme she wants to watch because he has time which he wants to use for other things.
column7: Do you think though that... that in... in a sense television skilled people's own er... sort of, creativity or their ability entertain themselves because if they're bored all they do is justturn on the television?
column8: Yes, I think that is a danger, and I think that.. in fact is what mishappening to a lot of people who use it as their... their main... um field of amusement and... because they don't have other outside interests and even when people come round they'll leave the television and not be, you know, particularly interested in talking to them, you Know the television will be the main thing in the room.

Then comes the hard part, a market analysis. You need to investigate and analyze hundreds of variables! You need to take into consideration socioeconomic factors from GDP per capita to how many children on average the population has! All this information is useful so that you can move on to your strategy and implementation stage, where you will describe in detail how you will actually execute your idea.

column7: Alright, come here and lay flat on your back. Let ’ s suppose this young woman has stopped breathing. We must lift the person ’ s chin so that we clear a pathway for air to get into the lungs. Then we place our mouth over the other person ’ s mouth and blow air two or three times, like this.
column8: Wait, what are you doing? I ’ m a married woman! You can ’ t just try to kiss me like this!
column9: Madam I ’ m not trying to kiss you! I am trying to demonstrate how to apply CPR in the case of an emergency.
column10: Well, OK. But no French kissing!
column11: As I was saying, we blow air through the mouth in this manner. Once this is done, we must try to get the heart going again. To do this, we place our hands over the person ’ s chest, and press down firmly two or three times.

column3: No, that ’ s May fifth in Spanish, James, no wonder you are failing my Spanish class. No, May first is International Workers ’ Day.

column7: In the nineteenth century, working conditions were appalling, with workers being forced to work ten, twelve, and fourteen hours a day. Support for the eight-hour work day movement was growing rapidly, despite the indifference and hostility of many union leaders, and by April 1886, 250,000 workers were involved in the May Day movement.Previous legislative attempts to improve working conditions had failed, so labor organizers took drastic measures. They passed a resolution stating that eight hours would constitute a legal day ’ s work. And, on May First 1886, the resolution took effect.
column8: Cool! Is that why we only work eight hours now?
column9: Yes! But the happy ending came at a high price.On May third, 1886, police fired into a crowd of strikers at the McCormick Reaper Works Factory, killing four and wounding many. A mass meeting was called for the next day to protest the brutality.
column10: And then what happened?
column11: Well, as we say, the rest is history...

It's not particularly beefy in construction, and generally, it won't stand up well under heavy loads or on really rough surfaces. In contrast, mountain bikes have wide tires and a stout frame. You sit higher on them and don't have to hunched over.

column1: Alright everyone settle down. Let ’ s get started.As you know, an important aspect of becoming a good citizen is understanding the genesis of our legal system. column7: In the nineteenth century, working conditions were appalling, with workers being forced to work ten, twelve, and fourteen hours a day. Support for the eight-hour work day movement was growing rapidly, despite the indifference and hostility of many union leaders, and by April 1886, 250,000 workers were involved in the May Day movement. Previous legislative attempts to improve working conditions had failed, so labor organizers took drastic measures. They passed a resolution stating that eight hours would constitute a legal day ’ s work. And, on May First 1886, the resolution took effect.
column8: Cool! Is that why we only work eight hours now?
column9: Yes! But the happy ending came at a high price.On May third, 1886, police fired into a crowd of strikers at the McCormick Reaper Works Factory, killing four and wounding many. A mass meeting was called for the next day to protest the brutality.
column10: And then what happened?
column11: Well, as we say, the rest is history...

column18: Yes, it happens.That is what happens in big snowstorms. People get stranded for days.

column1: What do you think are the most important things to do when running a business?
column2: Well, there are several things. Of course, you must do everything you can to keep costs down and revenues high.
column3: So, do you think workers should be paid as little as possible?
column4: No. if you do that, the workers won ’ t like their jobs. They will be less efficient and you will get a high staff turnover. Those things will increase you costs.
column5: How can a business maximise revenues?
column6: You need to invest in some good advertising. You have to know where your potential customers are and target them. It ’ s no good trying to sell computer games to older people. The market is too small.
column7: What else do you suggest?
column8: Find out what other companies charge for the same products or services. Price yourself near the low end. Don ’ t be much cheaper than everyone else, because many customers distrust very cheap things. They think that is must be poor quality if it ’ s that cheap.

I can help you on this exam. I will photocopy all my notes, and you can compare them to your notes.Then maybe you will see what kinds of things to write down.

I'm lucky because I had a good English teacher in high school.She taught me how to take good notes. It's not hard.

column1: Excuse me. Can you tell me how to find some books on social science?

column7: No, I don't think so. Sushi is a very delicately flavored food, and red wine would be a jarring contrast. You need a white wine, which has more subtle flavors, to complement the fish.
column8: I see. So should I get a bottle of Chardonnay? That's a white wine, right?
column9: Yes, Chardonnay is a white wine, but I'm not sure it'd be your best bet. Chardonnay is one of the more fullbodied whites, and tends to be a bit oaky. I'd suggest that you go for something brighter, like this Sauvignon Blanc from New Zealand.

column11: That's another varietal, or type of grape, just like Chardonnay.
column12: Let's see. The label says it's got " attractive citrus and grassy aromas that give way to crisp, mineral flavors and a bonedry finish. Serve chilled. " Oh, no, how long will it take to chill the wine? I'm on my way to the dinner now.
column13: It's OK, don't worry, we'll just choose a wine from the cooler. We don't have quite as extensive a selection over here, but... this Rhone Valley white would be lovely.
column14: All right. What varietal is that?
column15: Well, this is a French wine, so they don't always specify the varietal on the label. The French believe that the soil a grape is grown in is one of the most important factors in the final flavor of the wine. This wine is probably a blend of a few different types of grapes, mostly Viognier, I'd guess.
column16: And you think this is a good wine?
column17: Yes, this is one of our best-sellers. It's not quite as dry as the Sauvignon Blanc we were looking at earlier, which means it's more approachable. It's light and crisp, with a bit of a vanilla aroma.
column18: Perfect! I'll take it!

column1: Hey, Susan. Have you got a sec? I have some questions about my paycheck.

column3: Well, this is my first paycheck here in the States and there are a few things I don't understand. First of all, what is this FICA, and SUI Y tax, and why are there deductions both for Medicare and for my health insurance plan?
column4: OK, let's start from the top of your pay stub. This number here represents your gross pay.
column5: Then here we have a series of deductions. First off are the federal ones. FICA stands for Federal Insurance Contribution Act, or something like that. It's your federal income tax. And then there's Social Security and Medicare, which are both federal programs to help you out after you retire or if you were unable to work.
column6: All right, I see. So the Medicare isn't actually a health insurance I can use now.
column7: That's right. Below the federal deductions are the state deductions. There's the state income tax, and then this SUI / SDI tax you were asking about is paying into an unemployment and disability fund that our state has set up, but you can see it's a pretty small quantity that they take.
column8: Yeah, I don't mind giving them a dollar fifty for that. So there are two separate income taxes — one at a state level and one at a federal level?
column9: That's right. Not all states have an income tax. Some use higher property taxes or sales taxes instead.
column10: I see. All right, well I think everything else I can figure out on my own. The deductions for health insurance and my 401 ( K ) are pretty self-explanatory. Thanks for your help, Susan.
column11: No problem! All those deductions do add up, and nobody's net pay is as high as they'd like. I can understand why you'd want some explanation.
column12: Yeah, I guess it's the same in the UK, I just never paid much attention. See you later!

column1: There are so many environment problems in the world today. Do you think we can really solve them all or will destroy the world?

column4: Everyone is looking at the issue in the short term, rather than the long term. It ’ s the same with the destruction of the rainforests. Countries and companies just want the wood. They ’ re not thinking about the long-term damage to the forests. We should also remember that the forests are an important natural habitat for thousands of species of animal and plant life.
column5: In other parts of the world, especially in Africa, there is a problem with desertification. Climate change and over-farming are causing farmland to turn into desert. In means that people cannot grow enough food.
column6: It also means that people sometimes fight over the famp 3land that remains. Damaging the environment actually leads to conflict between people.

column1: The last thing to be ignored at a Chinese dinner table is to keep modest.

column3: No, absolutely not! On the contrary, you'll be considered a well-connected, sociable man, if you keep involved in the conversation all the time. But always pay attention to what you say. If the table has a senior guest, say something as upbeat and cheerful as possible. Or maybe, you may give the floor to him and keep listening as if very interested.
column4: You mean, keeping a low profile in the presence of the old? That goes in like with Confucius' preachings, right?
column5: Correct. Show respect for the older people. Conventionally, before the meal starts, the younger members are supposed to address each one of the elderly members of the table one by one. Others are kept in waiting until the most venerable guest proclaim the beginning of the meal and takes the first bite. Toasts also go to these men first before people can toast to each other.
column6: Any other rules to observe in order to keep modest?
column7: Yes, plenty of them. Don't eat fast! People usually keep their dining pace accorded with others. And all the dishes should not be eaten up completely.
column8: Is it because that would give the host the impression that the food was insufficient?
column9: Haha, I'm afraid it's simply because no one wishes to be too noticeable by finishing off the plate.

column1: You see, the bungee participants take a deep breath when they stand at the starting spot and then, like diving, their heads are over heels and they jump off into the realm of the combination of heaven and earth The wind roars at their ears and their bodies rapidly descend. They do not even have enough time to do several gymnastic movements and they are rebounded to the upper air by the cord.
column2: Entrusting life to the care of a rope indeed requires infinite courage.
column3: A young French fellow recalled his first bungee experience and said, When I fastened the cord and walked to the platform, I was extremely nervous. When I looked down, I was nervous even more.If the cord had broken, I would be knocked to bake meat. However, I knew my worries were unwanted. I was afraid if I retreated others might say something about me. I had to harden my heart and impose my head downward. I only felt wind wiring at my ears. My body rapidly descended. I thought that after only seven or eight seconds I was rebounded to upper air by the cord. In fact it was 30 seconds. Maybe because of my nervousness, I only felt seven or eight seconds. When rebounding to the high altitude, I felt a sudden sense of relief. I did not feel nervous very much, but very comfortable.
column4: It is hard to come by in life that you experience this kind of comfortable!

While lots of people spend time like an hour each morning exercising, a bike ride to work not only builds you up, but also makes full use of time. You might as well sleep out for a longer hour.
column5: I know cycling is always a more favorable choice than a bus. After all, it's a sport. But do you think it a pleasant experience to take in the dirty, polled air on the road?
column6: Well, such things are just unavoidable in a great metropolis like Beijing. I think a still more desirable benefit is psychological. Bicycling home after work can help release your stress. Life in the offices is miserable. You just sit there in a daze, gazing at the monitor and dealing with files and documents. Why don't you give a full play to your energy after work? Enjoy the speed on the road. Just think, you are flashing past the poles with your own energy. How great!

column6: Yeah, and they also take the blame, that's what happened to my old boss...

column10: So kung fu is also a means of self-cultivation, isn't it?

column1: It's my first visit to Prague, I'll be here for three days for a conference, then I have a day on my own to do some sightseeing before I head back home. What do you suggest I see when I'm here?

If you only have three or four days to visit, you don't want to spend them waiting in traffic in a cab. I suggest you take the subway.

column6: You can get a daily pass that will allow you to travel unlimited for the whole day for about 6 dollars. Otherwise, you can pay by trip, which is about 50 cents to 2 dollars each trip, depending on how far you go.

When the capital was moved to Beijing, no hill existed at this location, so one was constructed. It is called " Coal Hill ". Then you need a financial guarantee, and an application fee of 25 dollars.
column5: What's to come next?

column16: OK, then 50 Yuan for dessert. 500 Yuan all together.

column5: Yes.

column18: Well...

column22: Okay. I will try it. I suppose it isn't reasonable for me to refuse to go in.After all, gay people aren't afraid to go into normal bars.
column23: I'm glad you feel that way.We' ll leave in about ten minutes, alright?

column1: What do you think about all the different diets that people go on?
column2: I don't think dieting is good for you. It's much better to eat a balanced diet and to never get overweight to begin with!
column3: But what do you think about people who are obese? What should they do to lose weight?
column4: They need to eat healthy foods, but they also have to increase the amount of physical exercise every day. They don't have to cut out fattening foods altogether, though.
column5: So you think it's OK for people who are dieting to eat chocolate, don't you?
column6: Sure, they can eat some chocolate. As long as they are exercising and eating mostly healthy foods, there's nothing wrong with having a small dessert.
column7: How about drinking soda?
column8: Many people gain weight by drinking far too much soda. Soda should be treated seriously ; there's simply no nutritional value in it whatsoever.
column9: And have you ever tried taking vitamins?
column10: I used to take vitamins every day, but I don't take them anymore. Vitamins are good as a supplement, but they don't do much good if you don't have a well-balanced diet to start.
column11: How do you know so much about food and dieting?

column1: Are the galaxies in the universe moving through space?

column4: Well, the universe is a chaotic place, and the gravity from one galaxy, or from a group of galaxies, may disturb the motion of its near neighbors, causing them to collide. column8: I've heard about it a little bit before, but I don ’ t understand. How can people believe in God since they know God doesn't exist?
column9: That ’ s a little complicated. You ’ ll get to know it when you are acquainted with the U. S. history later on. Religion was and is a part of American people ’ s life. Guess what? Even Harvard University, which is a highly academic institution, is in a sense the product of religion.
column10: Really?
column11: Absolutely! It was founded by a group of Puritan immigrants from England.
column12: Why was it founded by the Puritans? Where were the atheistic educators?
column13: Because most of the first English immigrants who came to the United States were Puritans.
column14: How come? I mean why most of them were religious people?
column15: That ’ s because in the 16th and 17th century, there was a series of religious reforms in England. Many religious separatists were persecuted and fled to other countries.
column16: So, you mean people didn't enjoy religious freedom in England?
column17: Yes, that's why Puritans moved to the New World, where they believed they could establish a heaven for Puritans. Later on, it was these Puritans who founded Harvard College.
column18: Why did they want to found a college?
column19: Many Puritans had received classic style of higher education in Oxford University and Cambridge University back in England. They hoped that their descendants could receive this kind of education as well.
column20: Oh, I see.
column21: Actually Harvard was first named' New College', without a formal name.
column22: When did it begin to be called Harvard University?
column23: In 1639, it was renamed after its major benefactor John Harvard. Interestingly, JohnHarvard himself was a clergyman.
column24: It seems that Harvard was predestined to be influenced by religion.
column25: Therefore, it ’ s not exaggerate to claim that had there not been religion, there would note Harvard.
column26: Wow, I didn ’ t know that religion had played such an important role in Harvard history.
column27: Religion has been playing an indispensible part in Harvard history as well as the U. S.
column28: I finally begin to get to know Harvard. It seems that my knowledge of Harvard is rather poor. I have a lot work to do before applying for Harvard.
column29: Remember that Harvard is a part of the United States. So you have to know the U. S. history and culture if you want to have in-depth knowledge of Harvard. The two are closely related.
column30: That ’ s right. I have a lot to learn from you.

column1: Welcome back movie lovers to another Premier Movie Review. My name is Richard Clarke and I am joined today by the very erudite DavidWatson.
column2: Thank you Dick. Today we are going to talk about the movie Lion King. Tell me Dave, what is your impression of this film?
column3: Well, I think this film is simply a fable, depicting man ’ s eternal greed for power, and in my opinion, it ’ s a very fine film. Even despite the accusations of plagiarism traditional folk tales from other countries.The musical score was amazing, the animation was very well done, and the story was simply enchanting.
column4: I think otherwise. Even though the animation was technically strong, and as you say, the score and songs performed by Elton John were great, the film lacks a certain originality ; it lacked heart. And I would dare to say, it was too predictable.
column5: Predictable! How! Come on Dick, It ’ s a G-rated movie! It ’ s for the kids! It ’ s not a thriller!
column6: Well, that ’ s just it. It did have some very dramatic and intense scenes For example when Mufasal dies, or the dark, grim portrayal of Scar. Even so, the film is linear. Mufasal dies, Simba runs away thinking it ’ s his fault. Falls in love and returns to retake what is rightfully his. It ’ s just too cliche.
column7: How can it be cliche? It ’ s a fable! It ’ s telling a time-honoured story! The movie make a point of how the hunger for power leads to corruption, and teaches children the value of respect, life and love.
column8: You have always been so soft, Dave!
column9: Open your heart Dick. Don ’ t shut us out.
column10: Anyway... That ’ s all for today folks! Join us next time as we talk about & quot, How to lose a guy in 10 days & quot, I ’ m sure you ’ ll love that one Dave!

column1: Does tea-serving follow any special etiquette in China? Each time I dropped in at my Chinese friends' homes, their parents would offer me a cup of hot, strong tea, though they never inquired of me about whether I want it.
column2: You've got a point there. It is a custom and good manners to serve tea to a guest who comes to pay a visit. There is no need to ask if he needs it or not, or if he wants something else. It might be an insult to the guest if he is left sitting there without being served tea.
column3: So the guest is presumed to be thirsty and in need of some drink after the trip. In that case, I guess, in return, the guest doesn't have to drink it if he wouldn't like it.
column4: It wouldn't be considered rude behavior if he doesn't even take a single drop. But he'd better receive the teacup with both hands and bow his thanks when the cup is brought before his face. When the host pours hot water into his cup, he may also choose to tap his index finger on the table, meaning " Thanks ". No matter if he likes it or not, it is impolite if he doesn't even lay a finger on the cup.
column5: So next time, I'd better take a few sips, to' save face' at least, right?
column6: Sure. The guest is welcomed by being served tea. But if after chatting for a while, the host asks servants or family members to serve a new cup of tea, or add some hot water, he is giving another signal.
column7: What does that imply, then?
column8: More often than not, the understatement is' I'm afraid it's time you leave'.

column1: Look at this newspaper article about this famous local medium. It says that she is really gifted and so popular now, that she is booked solid with appointments for the next twelve months!

column3: Well, I have had many friends that went to a psychic and got their palms read and most of the things the psychic told her came true!
column4: Of course it does! They tell you general and obvious things like that you will be successful or have a big house. I think most of the times they are just scam artists.
column5: Well, historically it is a practice that many cultures share. Reading the tarot cards, in the east they would even read tea leaves! I even heard that there are people that make you smoke a cigar, and then read your ashes.
column6: All superstitious nonsense! I would still like to go to one and see what he or she has to say, just for kicks.

We like the same team, music, and most amazingly, we both love Chinese food! I have the feeling that we are going to be great friends.

column1: I used to think that Americans had so much money they didn ’ t know what to do with it.
column2: You did?

column4: What do you think now?
column5: There are lots of jobs, and almost everybody works. There is a high standard of living. People earn a lot, but they spend a lot to live. So there isn ’ t so much money after all.

column7: That ’ s true. But Americans work hard for their money like we do. I don ’ t know why our spending habits are so different.

column1: Did you read the letter in the paper about smoking? The person who wrote that must be crazy.

column3: Maybe so. But a law banning cigarettes will do no good.
column4: No, you can ’ t suddenly make smoking illegal, but government could prohibit smoking in public places like movies and theatres.

column5: You are absolutely right. They are too brief. They don't tell you anything.

column1: What's up? You look depressed.

column7: You got it! We'll fly there directly from Texas.

column1: I ’ m so relieved that your ankle wasn ’ t broken! I feel just awful about this whole thing. I wanna make it up to you. Let me take you out to dinner tonight. My treat.

column7: I woke up today thinking this would be just like any other ordinary day, but I was wrong. A twist of fate brought us together. I crashed into your life and you into mine, and this may sound crazy, but I ’ m falling in love with you, Veronica.

column6: Only since this morning.
column7: Oh, probably you've been working too hard.
column8: Maybe you are right.

column5: But that ’ ll affect the national economy.
column6: That ’ s right. But I don ’ t think there are better ways.

column8: Maybe it can take effect.

column4: It ’ s a prediction of your month, based on your zodiac sign. You have a different sign for the month and date you were born in. I was born on April 15th, so I ’ m an Aries. When were you born?
column5: January 5th.
column6: Let ’ s see... you ’ re a Capricorn. It says that you will be feeling stress at work, but you could see new, exciting developments in your love life. Looks like we ’ ll both have interesting summers!
column7: That ’ s bogus. I don ’ t feel any stress at work, and my love life is practically nonexistent. This zodiac stuff is all a bunch of nonsense.

column9: Well, you certainly match those criteria, but they ’ re so broad they could apply to anyone. What does it say about me?
column10: A Capricorn is serious-minded and practical. She likes to do things in conventional ways. That sounds just like you!

column1: Well, you seem to enjoy speaking English.

column5: You know, speaking in class is a very good chance to put your English to practical use.

column4: I don't understand of myself. It seems they have to save money.

column1: What did you cook?
column2: Well, as you know I was in Thailand last month, and I took a cooking class! So I prepared some of my favorite dishes.

column7: This is delicious! The combination of sour and spicy is really interesting! I could have this everyday!
column8: Ok, now for the last and best dish in my opinion. This is called Pad Thai. It's stir-fried noodles with eggs, fish sauce, tamarind juice, red chili pepper plus bean sprouts, shrimp and tofu and garnished with crushed peanuts and coriander. It's practically Thailand's national dish!
column9: Wow, this is great! I never knew Thai food was so creative and delicious!

column1: Hey! How was your first day of class? I ’ m in level two and I ’ m loving my class this semester! It ’ s great being in a class of international students!

column3: That ’ s both fortunate and unfortunate. It ’ s the United Nations in my class! We have people from all over the world! There are three Germans, a Pole, a Scottish, two French, an American, a Brazilian, a Chilean, a New Zealander, though he prefers to call himself a Kiwi. Who else do we have? Oh, we also have a Moroccan, a Togolese, a Pakistani, and two Indonesians!
column4: That ’ s quite the array of nationalities. Everyone in my class is from Asia, except me. There are a few South Koreans, several Japanese, Malaysian, Thai, Singaporean, Filipino, Kazakhstan, and one Russian.

column6: I guess so, but I think it ’ s going to be hard to relate to my classmates, especially with the language barrier. I think I might change classes.
column7: Don ’ t! Stay the course! Your spoken Chinese will be eternally grateful. I bet you it will even surpass mine with all that practice.
column8: I highly doubt it. Your girlfriend is Chinese.

column1: Those are the headlines for today, and now for the international weather report with Mike Sanderson.
column2: Thank you, Bob! This past week has been the beginning of Armageddon for many, a series of unprecedented meteorological events occurred around the world. In Switzerland, a major avalanche was reported in the Alps. Fortunately, no one was injured. Due to to the extreme cold this winter, a blizzard has struck the US Midwest, causing classes in schools and universities to be temporarily canceled. Moving to to Latin American, Ecuador has suffered a six month drought that has not only affected farming, but has also forced the closure of the hydroelectric power plant that provides electricity for the entire country. In Chile, a major earthquake that registered seven point five on the Richter scale struck the southern region. Losses are reported to be in the billions. Authorities have not yet released an official statement.
column3: Not a great week for the world! Any good news?
column4: I ’ m afraid not, Bob. One of the major volcanoes in Mexico has erupted, causing major floods and landslides in the region. Meanwhile, Mexico ’ s coast has been hit by hurricane Liliana and officials say that all the seismic activity leads them to believe that a tsunami may hit Central America, affecting Honduras, Guatemala and Panama. That ’ s all the news we have for today, but stay tuned for updates on the six o ’ clock news. Back to you Bob.

Then you need a financial guarantee, and an application fee of 25 dollars.
column5: What's to come next?
column6: If they agree to enroll you, they will send you a TAP - 66 Form. With TAP - 66, you can apply for a passport from our government, and then apply for a visa from the US Embassy in Beijing.

It comes from the information technology industry.. there isn't such a large division between home and office, so people want to work in the clothes they feel more relaxed in.

column1: In spring, people are feeling refreshed. They take off their heavy winter clothes and walk with a straight back and light steps. They feel they are full of spirits and energy.
column2: Women in particular. They are anxious to get rid of those thick and clumsy winter suits and put on their new fashionable spring dress.
column3: Well, when summer comes, the weather is hot and the leaves turn darkgreen ; the sun is blazing and the air is threatening. No one would like to stay in the open air for long.
column4: That's true. In summer, the first place people want to go is a spacious room with air-conditioning or a quiet river or swimming pool.
column5: I myself like very much to listen to the singing of some of the insects, especially the singing of cicadas.
column6: In autumn, almost all fruits are ripe and all crops are waiting to be harvested.
column7: And you can hear singing and laughing everywhere! People are happy in autumn because autumn brings them harvest and richness and prosperity!
column8: Well, winter is a season for relaxation, do you agree with me?
column9: Well, it's hard to say. For the fields and rivers, winter is a relaxing season, but for farmers, I think they might take a rest physically, but mentally they are still busy thinking, planning and calculating for the working of the next year.
column10: Maybe you are right.

column11: Gotcha... OK. Here they are.
column12: Now wash them, then dice the potatoes and bell peppers.
column13: Where's the peeler?

column1: Hey Jane. How are you doing these days?
column2: Hi Martha. Everything is perfect.
column3: Are you enjoying married life?
column4: It couldn't be better. My husband is so supportive with my work and he helps around the house so much.
column5: You're so lucky. I hope to get married to a guy like that.
column6: I'm so happy. Even though we are both working, we get to spend a lot of time with each other in the evening and on the weekends.
column7: Do you guys do anything special?
column8: In the evening, we just sit and talk over dinner. But on the weekend, we try to go out to the beach or hit a nice restaurant, or go to a nice cafe.
column9: Sound like everything is great.

column1: Dad, how can we get to the zoo?
column2: We can take a bus there.
column3: Does this bus go there?
column4: I think so.
column5: Let's step in, Dad.
column6: No, it's too crowded.
column7: Dad. Here comes another bus.
column8: Fine. Let's get on. Oh, no, Judy! Get off the bus quickly!
column9: Why? Dad?
column10: We got on the wrong bus.

column1: Good evening, sir. What's your pleasure this evening? Your usual?
column2: Yes. I'm going to stay with the same, a beer.
column3: Certainly, a beer. Here you are, sir.
column4: Oh, darn. Look what I've done. ( Spill the drink )
column5: Don't worry. I'll make you another on the house.

column1: Are we going to have gym class tomorrow?
column2: Are you crazy? Tomorrow's Saturday.
column3: Sometimes I forget that we don't have school on Saturdays.
column4: Americans also don't go to work on Saturdays.
column5: So there are only five working days in a week?
column6: Right. What are you going to do tonight?
column7: I'm going to study.
column8: On a Friday night?
column9: Well, I need to polish up my English.

column1: You look so tan and healthy!
column2: Thanks. I just got back from summer camp.
column3: How was it?
column4: Great. I got to try so many things for the first time.
column5: Like what?
column6: I went sailing, fishing, and horseback riding.
column7: I ’ m so jealous.
column8: The counselors were so nice too. It was the best summer ever. Except for all those mosquitoes!

column1: Long time no see!
column2: Yes. It has been a long time since the last time we met.
column3: It's nice to see you again. Have you changed jobs?
column4: No. I've been visiting relatives recently.
column5: That's nice. Where have you been?
column6: I went to visit an uncle in San Francisco.
column7: Are you busy now?
column8: No. Why?
column9: How about a coffee in that cafe?
column10: Great. Let's talk over coffee.

column1: This shirt is really nice.
column2: You have a very good taste, sir. Would you like to try it on?
column3: OK. I'll try on a medium size.
column4: Here you are
column5: Where is the fitting room?
column6: It's just around the comer.
column7: It's too big tor me. Do you have a smaller one?
column8: Yes. One moment, please.

column1: Oriental China Airlines. Good morning, may I help you?
column2: I would like the round-way ticket to Shanghai on December 10th.
column3: Lady, let me check. Do you want the morning or the afternoon flight?
column4: What's the departure time?
column6: Well, the afternoon will be fine.
column7: First class or economy?
column8: First class will be preferred.
column9: Well, afternoon flight on December 10th to Shanghai. May I have your name, please?
column10: My name is Janice. Well, I book this ticket for Nova, the marketing manager of Pineapple Computer Company. Where can I get the flight ticket?
column11: You may take it up at the ticket office. That is located on International Street 150.

column1: I ’ d like to send this parcel to Australia.
column2: Certainly. Could you put it on the scales, so I can check the weight?
column3: Sure. It ’ s not very heavy.
column4: That ’ s 850 grams. The coasts depends on how you would like to send it.
column5: I see. What are the options? I suppose airmail is faster and more expensive than surface mail.
column6: That ’ s right. Sending it by airmail will cost twelve dollars and sending it by surface mail will cost eight dollars.
column7: How long will it take to get there?
column8: Airmail should take four or five days and surface mail should take about two weeks.
column9: It that case, I ’ ll send it by airmail. I ’ d like to send it as a registered parcel.
column10: No problem. That ’ s one dollar extra.
column11: Thanks very much. There ’ s thirteen dollars.
column12: There ’ s you receipt. Goodbye.

column1: I'll have a whole-wheat loaf, three white loaves, a baguette and ten rolls, please. How much is that?
column2: The whole-wheat loaf is 45 cents, the white loaves are 35 cents each, the baguette is 27 cents and the rolls are eight cents each. That makes two dollars fifty-seven cents.
column3: There you go.
column4: Thank you, ma'am. Forty-three cents change. Have a nice day.

column1: Do you shop online often?
column2: Every so often. It is very convenient and the price is lower than in stores.
column3: Are there many things online?
column4: Books, cosmetics, daily necessities, even large electrical appliance can be ordered from online-stores.
column5: Incredible. I really want to survey the on-line virtual supermarket.
column6: Even you can bargain with the owner of one on-line store, although he or she provides' But It Now' prices.
column7: What are the disadvantages of on-line shopping?
column8: Some provide wrong pictures for the goods, so many buyers are deceived.

column1: The road ahead is blocked. There might have been an accident.
column2: Are there many accidents in the city every day?
column3: Not really, but they are on the rise.
column4: Please drive slowly, we've got lots of time. Safety first.

column1: Hi. I need a wake-up call tomorrow.
column2: What time would you like your wake-up call?
column3: I need two calls, one at 7 and another at 7 fifteen.
column4: That is no problem at all, of course. You'll get a call at 7 o'colock and another at 7 fifteen.
column5: Then again, I think 7 fifteen is too early. Change 7 fifteen to 7 thirty, please.
column6: So, that'll be a call at 7 and another at 7 thirty.Do you have any other requests?
column7: Not just now, but if I do think of something later, I'll give you a ring.
column8: Okay, sir. Sleep well.

column1: Let's get together this weekend, is that all right?
column2: Sounds good, when?
column3: When is it convenient for you?
column4: Any time is fine.
column5: Could you and your wife be ready at nine o'clock?
column6: Please wait for us even if we're a little late.
column7: Never mind. I'll be waiting for you.
column8: See you then.
column9: OK. Bye!

column1: We will go to Luoyang for a vacation next month.
column2: How long will you stay there?
column3: About one week.
column4: Where will you live during the vacation.
column5: In the hotel.
column6: Have you made a reservation?
column7: Yes, we have.
column8: That's OK.

column1: What a wonderful game!
column2: Yes, the weather is wonderful, the game is wonderful and the players are wonderful.
column3: I think John is the best player on the field.
column4: He certainly is. He is the Peckham in our collage.
column5: Maybe he shouldn ’ t come to collage, he should become a football star.

column1: Mr. : Please open your books to page 10. ( To Mary ) Can I help you?
column2: I'm sorry that I'm late. I couldn't find the room.
column3: Mr. : That's alright. It's the first day of school, after all.
column4: What are we doing?
column5: Mr. : I'm asking the class to read page 10 to themselves. Then I'm going to ask some questions about the passage.
column6: May I have a book?
column7: Mr. : Here. Write your name inside the front cover. Remember that you must return the textbook to me at the end of the semester, so keep it in good condition.

column1: Wow! It's hot today! Do you want to get an ice cream cone?
column2: No Let's go to an ice cream parlor! They have way more flavors to choose from there. I feel like having something special like Neapolitan ice cream.
column3: What's that?
column4: It's three different flavors mixed together. Chocolate, strawberry and something green with candied fruit.
column5: Do they have ice cream bars. frozen yogurt or frozen chocolate mousse?
column6: Absolutely! They also have real Italian Galatian and French sorbets. They do a great baked Alaska.
column7: Maybe a vanilla ice cream milkshake would be good. What's your favorite flavor?
column8: Well... l like the traditional flavors like rum raisin, butter pecan. maple walnut, strawberry, chocolate and vanilla. But now there are some new flavors from Asia like green tea and durian.
column9: God! Even talking about it makes me feel like l'm gaining weight!
column10: That's OK. We can go jogging, after we eat!

column1: Come on, darling. We haven't got much time.
column2: All right. I'm nearly ready. What time does the bus leave?
column3: Half past six... and it's half past six already.
column4: Oh, we've got plenty of time.
column5: We haven't. Hurry up!
column6: All right. Let's go.
column7: And about time too!

column1: Our team just scored a goal.
column2: That's more like it.
column3: Tell me about it.
column4: They might actually win the game.

column1: Mike! Look at the floor!
column2: What's wrong with it?
column3: What's wrong with it? It's filthy!
column4: Oh...
column5: It's filthy because you never wipe your shoes.
column6: Sorry, love.
column7: What are you looking for now?
column8: My cigarettes.
column9: Well, they' re not here.They are in the dustbin.
column10: In the dustbin! Why didn't you tell me before?

column1: Hello, John. How are you?
column2: I'm fine, thanks. And you?
column3: Very well, thanks. Nice to see you again. I haven't seen you for a long time. What have you been doing lately?
column4: Oh, nothing much really. And how is everything with you?
column5: Fine, thanks. I've been busy lately.
column6: What have you been doing?
column7: I've been studying for my exams. My school exams will begin next month.
column8: Really? Good luck for them.
column9: Thanks. And how are your parents?
column10: They're both very well, thanks.
column11: Where are you going now?
column12: I'm going to do some shopping.Why don't you come with me?
column13: I can't. I have to meet someone.
column14: It's been nice talking to you.
column15: Good-bye. See you again sometime.

column1: I need to know why I'm being charged $ 10 for a movie that I never ordered.
column2: Hmm. Your file shows that you watched' Titanic' Monday night.
column3: Monday night? Monday night I was at a great concert.
column4: Well, as they say, garbage in, garbage out. Let me correct this error, please.
column5: Thank you. It's very nice when problems can be solved quickly.
column6: When I deleted the $ 10, the computer automatically added a $ 2 service charge.
column7: Are you crazy? You made the mistake and now you're charging me for your mistake?
column8: Sir, if it makes you feel any better, the $ 2 service fee used to be $ 5.
column9: Why don't you just stick a gun in my ribs and take everything I have?
column10: Unfortunately, sir, you'll have to pay the $ 2, whether you like it or not.

column1: I went shopping without my umbrella yesterday morning.
column2: Yesterday morning was beautiful I thought the sunning was going to continue.
column3: So did I. that's why I didn't take my umbrella. I got cold in the rain in the afternoon. It was raining cats and dogs.
column4: I know. I could not believe it when I got hit by that storm. It was pouring with rain all afternoon.
column5: We really have some movable weather sometime. I wish I would live somewhere which were sunning all year round.
column6: If it was sunning all year round there would be drought. You probably would not like it either.
column7: I guess you are right. Maybe I just wish the weather could be a little more predictable.
column8: The weather forecasters are not good at predicting the weather would be like. Our weather is so changeable.

column1: I've been looking forward to the new semester.
column2: I hope we can make great progress in this new semester.
column3: Hope so.
column4: I hear we'll have a new English teacher this semester.
column5: Really? I hope we will do much better under her guidance.
column6: I am sure we will.

column1: Did you find what you were looking for?
column2: I tried when you had gone, but I had no luck.
column3: Okay, let's both look for it now.
column4: Okay.

column1: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
column2: Good morning. I'm interested in antiques. Do you have any?
column3: Yes, we have a great variety of Chinese antiques.
column4: What do you have?
column5: Well, we have some painting and some porcelain. Which do you like better?
column6: I'd like porcelain.
column7: Good. How about the table set?
column8: Oh, it looks well. I like it very much.
column9: It's made in Jingdezhen.
column10: How much is it?
column11: One thousand eight hundred yuan.
column12: It's not expensive. I'll take it.

column1: Are you going to the beach this saturday afternoon?
column2: It depends on the weather.
column3: The radio says it'll be fine.
column4: That'll be great.
